text:
Hello !

I've Installed the Newly GA Release of Apache 2 (.0.35) D/Led from the 
Apache.org Site , an Chosen to Start it Manually (on Port 8080) .

I've Ran it more than twice (rebooting before each new start - details to 
follow ...)

After Each Time I've Started it , I Was Unable to Terminate it :
Not via using CTRL+C , not via the Console window's "X" , not via the "Task 
Manager" and Even not via "Log Off ..." !

Two (2) times from those I've Tried to Terminate it - I Got the BSoD saying 
something ala :
"PROCESS_HAS_LOCKED_PAGES" ...

Seems like a Weird Bug to me ,
as till i've tried to Close it , it has Worked as Charm - it even Ran my PHP 
Scripts (with PHP 4.2.0-dev as CGI) !

My Config. :
---
CPU = AMD Duron 1.1Ghz
MEM = 256MB
HDD = >20GB Free
OS = Win2K.Server , Patch Level = SP2 + SP2.SRP1
Logged as : Administrator (me)
---
creator: x86zman@bigfoot.com

text: *** Bug 7941 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
creator: wrowe@apache.org

text: *** Bug 8270 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
creator: jwoolley@apache.org

text:
Would someone who can reproduce the error please provide exact details?

First reproduce the error and jot down ALL the details.  There is a
program at www.sysinternals.com that lets you capture a BSoD screen
shot when one occurs.

Then follow the directions at;

  http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;EN-US;q256010

and again capture the exact BSoD.  Post the two error details to
this bug report.

Thanks
creator: wrowe@apache.org

text:
I've Edited the Registry as Written on that M$ KB Article ,
and It Seems that Apache Clashes with AFD.SYS (which contains : "Ancillary 
Function Driver for WinSock")

and This is what BlueSave has managed to Capture , HTH :

creator: x86zman@bigfoot.com
dfrazier@solutionmetrics.com
text:
I'll have to set up a test server this weekend.

I had been working with a production server, and stepped Apache and tomcat back 
to the previous releases (1.3.24 and 3.3.x) to solve the interim problem.

Additionally, 

I noticed a common element:
Zone Alarm appears in the BSOD capture: 
I am also running ZA at revision 3.0.118.
creator: dfrazier@solutionmetrics.com
hoju@visi.com
text:
I am having the same problem, only I am running Apache 2.0.35 as a service.  I
am also running Zone Alarm Pro, v.3.0.091 on Win2k (sp2sr1).

I have hit the BSoD about 4 times.  It always happens a few minutes after I
attempt to stop the Apace2 service.  The service applet will report that Apache2
hasn't responded to the shutdown notice and will just sit there for a while.  I
just wait a few minutes doing other things and then, Bang!  BSoD with
"PROCESS_HAS_LOCKED_PAGES".  The only way to get Apache2 to restart is to reboot
my machine.

I have also noticed that after running Apache for most of the day, it is now
unresponsive to new requests.  Again, the only way to get it running properly
again is to reboot my machine.

Jake

Here is what I get in my BSoD after editing the registry per the MS article:

*** STOP: 0x000000CB (0xBF65C674, 0xBF65C845, 0x85330468, 0x81213134) 
DRIVER_LEFT_LOCKED_PAGES_IN_PROCESS
This driver may be at fault: afd.sys
*** Address BF65C674 base at BF659000, DateStamp 3a68ba63 - afd.sys
*** Adresss BF65C845 base at BF659000, DateStamp 3a68ba63 - afd.sys

I did install the BlueSave program, but it just printed a bunch of garbled 
text.  It does say that it is only for Windows NT, so it is probably not 
compatible with win2k.  I'm using Win2k Professional, not Server, BTW.

I think this link with Zone Alarm Pro 3.xx is a definite possibility because I 
installed this Apache 2.0.35 at work (which doesn't have Zone Alarm installed) 
and everything seemed to run fine allowing me to start and stop the service as 
needed with no BSoD issues.

I hope this can be fixed soon!  I'll have to drop back to 1.3.24 for now.

Jake
creator: hoju@visi.com
slive@apache.org
text:
This is obviously ZoneAlarm messing up the windows sockets interface.
I'll leave the bug open in case someone can propose a workaround for the
Apache code, but the best workaround is just to remove ZoneAlarm.

creator: hoju@visi.com
text:
Ahhh, no offense, Joshua, but that is just plain sillyness.  You are joking, 
right?  So if there is a conflict between Apache software and another vendor, 
just blame the other vendor and call it a day?  Here are the reasons why that 
statement makes no sense whatsoever:

1. Apache 1.3.xx works just fine with Zone Alarm even if Zone Alarm is, 
supposedly, "messing up the windows sockets interface".  If so, why does Apache 
work just fine and Apache2 doesn't? 

2. There are reasons why I have Zone Alarm installed in the first place so 
telling me to just "remove Zone Alarm" in order to run Apache2 is just plain 
Arrogant.  Basically you are saying that your software is more important than 
other software.  I'll just move back to Apache 1.3.24 to, temporarily, solve 
the issue; not uninstall a program that performs an important function on my 
networked machine.

3.  Lots of other software seems to run just fine with Zone Alarm including 
other types of servers (Apache 1.2.34, Serv-u FTP, Tomcat 3.3.1/4.1-dev, etc...)

4.  Zone Alarm could simply be exposing a subtle flaw in Apache2 which is 
something you seem unwilling to consider.  Maybe it is the other way around?  
Who knows?  Either way, the issue certainly deserves more investigation than 
you seem think is worthwhile.

Please let me know if my statements are totally invalid and, if so, provide 
your reasoning.  I think they are quite reasonable and it would certainly put 
Apache2 in a better light if it worked with pretty much *the* most popular 
personal firewall on Windows.

I love open source and I think Apache does a tremendous job developing open 
source software, but it irks me when open source developers just blow off valid 
issues like this.  There is an issue and there is a chance it might be a bug in 
Apache2.  If so, the solution is to fix Apache2.  If not, the solution is to 
alert Zone Alarm that (and, ideally, how) they are breaking a Apache2 so they 
can get things working properly on their end.  Either way, Apache2 users 
benefit and everyone is happy.

Jake

Take it easy, budy.

The reason I suspect a bug in ZoneAlarm is because we've seen many similar
problems in the past with various versions of Apache, and they usually turn
out to be caused by the firewall software failing to properly impliment
an interface that they replace from the OS.  Apache 2.0 uses many different
functions that Apache 1.3, so it is not surprising that it tickles different
bugs in other software.

That is not to say that it is impossible that there is a bug in Apache.  But the
fact is that ZoneAlarm is a very invasive program that replaces big chunks of the
operating system.  Apache, on the other hand, just uses the APIs.  And since
Apache is working fine with the APIs provided by Win32, but not working with
the replacements provided by ZoneAlarm, it is likely that ZoneAlarm has
mis-implimented something.
creator: slive@apache.org
hoju@visi.com
text:
Ok, taking it much easier now.  Sorry for the diatribe.  Your current 
explanation provides a better context for your first comments.  It is now clear 
to me that you weren't just blowing off this issue.  

It still would be nice if someone with knowledge of the inner workings of 
Apache would install Zone Alarm and Apache2 together and track down the cause 
of, first, the service not being able to shut down, and second, the BSoD.  The 
problem is pretty easy to replicate.  I think it would be time well spent.  I 
would attempt this myself, but I am not much of a C/C++ programmer and don't 
have much of an idea of how I would debug something like this?

I'll go ahead a let Zone Labs know that there seems to be a conflict between 
Zone Alarm and Apache2, see what they have to say and report that back here.

Jake

Here's what I got back from Zone Labs Technical Support...

<ZoneLabsResponse>
Thank you for your report. We are aware of the problem that causes the 
PROCESS_HAS_LOCKED_PAGES error.

The PROCESS_HAS_LOCKED_PAGES error generally only occurs on Windows 2000 or XP, 
and is a consequence of a change in Windows architecture that occurred in 
Windows 2000.  It may show up when using NetMeeting.

We are working on this problem, and expect that a fix will be available in a 
future release.
</ZoneLabsResponse>

So, looks like it most definitely is Zone Alarm that is the culprit.  I'll post 
another message when I hear from them that the issue is fixed and then close 
out this bug report.

Jake
creator: hoju@visi.com

text: *** Bug 8779 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
creator: wrowe@apache.org

text:
Please try the new Apache 2.0.36 and report back.  We have changed the way
  the socket is instantiated, perhaps this will affect ZoneAlarm.

  But I'm afraid, with our source code publicly available, and their code
  problematic to debug, we all need to defer to their developers.  I'm closing
  this bug as irrelevant to the Apache developers.
creator: wrowe@apache.org
gary@loescher.org
text:
2.0.36 exhibits the same BSoD behavior with ZoneAlarm, unfortunately.

Does anyone know of a good firewall that plays nicely with Apache 2 on Win2k 
etc platforms?

Gary

Just as Gary said ,
this Bug is still live as of yet - even if the problem source is not in 
Apache ... yet it's a Known _Open_ Issue !
creator: x86zman@bigfoot.com

text:
As a point of fact, we don't track OS or third party bugs [ZoneAlarm cites 
  incompatibility with NetMeeting as well, indicating this is a pretty deep
  problem in their software or the WinSock layer.]  Sorry if you disagree.
  Reopen if you have a patch that fixes the problem, or we can reproduce without
  ZoneAlarm installed.

  Do not reopen, otherwise.  However, feel free to annotate with any useful
  details, especially ZoneAlarm's bug fix release.

  I also disagree with your MPM assessment, it's only half of the issue
  (most of the networking code is in the APR layer, not the MPM, although
  the MPM does manage the listener pool.)  I'm reverting to All to reflect
  that it might be an interaction between components.

  To Gary Loescher's question; there is a report [different in nature, but
  a problem] in bug #8729 reported against Sygate Firewall.  I have seen no 
  reports of other firewall software misbehaving.  Not trusting in firewall
  software, I'm afraid my only point of reference are external appliances.
  If you use an external DSL router or similar, you aught to configure it 
  rather than entrusting WinSock-based software on a real box.
creator: wrowe@apache.org

text:
I've found that Even the Lastest ZoneAlarm_Pro 3.0.133 got the Same Issue...

_BUT_ i've found a Workaround (that worked for me at least !) :
Before Closing Apache2, Shut-down ZoneAlarm (and Wait a few Sec. till it unloads
fully) - now you may Close Apache2 safely !
creator: x86zman@bigfoot.com
x86zman@bigfoot.com
text:
I've found that Even the Lastest ZoneAlarm_Pro 3.0.133 got the Same Issue...

_BUT_ i've found a Workaround (that worked for me at least !) :
Before Closing Apache2, Shut-down ZoneAlarm (and Wait a few Sec. till it unloads
fully) - now you may Close Apache2 safely !

The problem still exists between Apache 2.0.39 and ZoneAlarm 3.1.291.  I had to
do a slight modification of the workaround posted by Moran Zaltsman to get it to
work properly.  It wasn't enough just to stop ZoneAlarm before I stopped Apache,
I had to also start Apache before I started ZoneAlarm, otherwise it didn't work.
 So the modified work-around I offer up is this:
<start Apache>
   <start ZoneAlarm>
      ...
   <stop ZoneAlarm>
<stop Apache>
creator: deus777@earthling.net
wrowe@apache.org
text:
If you modify the service dependencies of ZoneAlarm to require the Apache2
service to start first, you will create the behavior you are looking for.

  If you start either ZoneAlarm or Apache2, they will start in the correct order.

  If you stop Apache2, ZoneAlarm will be stopped as well.

  However, I can't promise that shutdown behaves properly, MS lets all the 
services simply begin slamming closed without paying as much attention to
dependencies on the way out [that's how they made shutdowns much faster than
back in the NT 4.0 days.]

text:

*** Bug 12284 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
creator: wrowe@apache.org
wrowe@apache.org
text: *** Bug 12506 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I was able to reproduce the error, and in my original posting I put the exact 
details.  When someone decided my error report was this one, I don't know what 
happened to the report.  In any event, running zone alarm with apache at this 
point is asking for trouble.

The system actually ran and served pages but invariably after a short time, I 
would get the BSOD and a message about PROCESS HAS LOCKED PAGES.  Apparently 
Zone Alarm replaces a lot of the networking functionality in Windows, and there 
is a but in their code.  As soon as Zone Alarm was removed, the server hasn't 
gone down.

I never experienced the 'unable to stop apache' issue, but once you get the 
BSOD, the system is locked and requires a manual hard reset.   It could be that 
some people are not getting to the BSOD before their system locks.

I continue to run Zone Alarm on all other machines with no problems from any 
applications, but none are as robust as Apache, and I expect none get at the 
network layer to the extent it does.

System: 750 Mhz Compaq, XP Pro, Zone Alarm and Apache current updates.
creator: umina@theuminas.com

text:
With all due respect folks, the solution that users like myself have found is 
to bail on Apache2 and revert to 1.3. I've seen no other conflicts between 
ZoneAlarm and other applications, including NetMeeting, which I use frequently. 
This is not just an inconvenience with Apache2. It does not merely BSOD when 
you attempt to stop the Apache2 service. Long before that, Apache2 silently 
ceases to operate, apparently whenever it hits a threshold requiring that it 
spawn another child or has used a certain number of threads. Tinkering with 
those settings alters the length of time until failure. The BSOD occurs *after* 
functionality already has been lost due to this failure. Meanwhile, objecting 
to ZoneAlarm is like objecting to MacAfee or Norton. In many environments, it 
isn't a choice whether the user will install it. It is mandated by 
institutional policies. If Apache2 can't work with it, Apache2 is the one to 
go. I understand the difficulty in debugging closed source vs. open source. But 
I honestly believe it's in Apache's interest to work more closely with 
ZoneAlarm on this one. Otherwise, at least within the low-volume server 
community, it's Apache, not ZoneAlarm, who's going to get a black eye among 
users.
creator: meyer@newslink.org

text:
Eric, I can't argue with the particulars of anything you've said.
This problem certainly does hurt apache among a certain group of
users.  But it is also fairly clear that the problem is one in 
ZoneAlarm and not one in Apache.

You are also correct about the way to get the problem fixed: convince
ZoneAlarm that is important.  I strongly encourage you to have a go 
at this yourself.  You, and other members of the Apache user community,
should contact ZoneAlarm and try to convince them that this problem
is important enough to be fixed.  Apache is a volunteer organisation,
so things get done only when individuals take them on and do them.

[As far as the status of this bug, the fact that it is closed does not
mean that it is not important.  It just means that it does not identify
a problem in the Apache source code.  If we had an "Advocacy" category
like Mozilla, I suppose we could file it there.]
creator: slive@apache.org

text:
I have personally seen plenty of other wierd behavior when zonealarm
is present, which magically went away when zonealarm was deactivated
or removed.

1) listening sockets get stuck "on" so that if the listening
application crashes, the socket is unusable until the system
is rebooted.

2) Interference, somhow, wiht a TCP stream throughput. The
stream in question send short messages in both directions,
not strictly in query/response pattern.  Under zonealarm
and some undetermined boundary conditions, throughput on
this channel becomes very low, like 1 message per minute.

3) Impossible to get rid of "service failed to start" errors
(except by removing zonealarm) for zonealarm's underlying 
monitoring service.

4) windows NT became unbootable after the most recent zonealarm upgrade.
This one really scared me, so I threw out zonealarm altogether.

I've had zero substantive response from zonelabs on these issues.
creator: ddyer@real-me.net
bojan@rexursive.com
text:
Although this one has been beaten to death, I just wanted to add one comment.
Even if Apache2 attempted to do the worst things possible to the kernel, the
kernel should not crash. I never used Apache (any version) on Windows, but it
doubt that any of its components run in kernel mode. So, you have to focus on
something that does run in kernel mode.

Bojan

I also report this bug on my Pentium III 1ghz. I actually quit using 2.0.40 
and went back to 1.3.26. 2.0 would stop responding and then Bsod would appear 
when trying to shut down. I have Zonealarmn 3.0 installed too.

creator: nicodeimous@lfa.dns2go.com
text:
Just for those of you who think that reverting back will help far any amount of 
time, your simply retarding the effectiveness of your web servers.  Apache2 
isn't the only web server effected by this ZA bug.  Deerfields Website is also 
effected.  So it seems that if you want to run any recent webserver on a 
machine, ZA isn't the best option to go with for firewall protection.

I stumbled upon this site, and I must thank you guys for your work on chasing a 
bug thats very annoying.  Your one of the FEW places where I have found even a 
glimmer of an answer to whats BSODing a server that has been stable for over a 
year.  I recently installed ZA pro and soon after the webserver became 
unresponsive, then BSOD and restart.  I refused to beleive that ZA could do 
this and weeded through all my programs that had access to the network, tried 
many suggested remedies and yet it still got the BSOD.  

I know you guys hate to debug other peoples problems and I agree that you 
shouldn't be responsible for doing it.  With that said, Thanxs, your discovery 
was the answer for my webservers woes, fixed itself imediately after removing 
ZA.

Nicodeimous Chanye

ulrich.lange.dv@t-online.de
text:
Hallo together,

STOP 0x00000076

W2K 5.00.2195 SP3
Apache 2.0.44
ZoneAlarm 3.1.395
afd.sys 5.0.2195.4667

If I start my system apache in this configuration works very well all over the
day, but if I stop the apache process at any time, the service hangs and blue
screen occurs in 3 - 5 minutes. I located the problem in driver afd.sys. without
apache the system works ok. I think the problem can found in the communication
between apache and afd.sys at stopping time.

Ulrich

Read this entire bug before reopening.  You will see there is nothing
  we can do about poorly written network filters, and you will see citations
  to the vendor's comments and forthcoming release.

text:
Gentlemen, just a last word from me about Zone Alarm.
Do not waste more time and resources on this. ZA up to version 2.6 was ok.
Since version 3.xx the product is A PILE OF RUBBISH !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!.
I had to take it away from my server. One day without warning it closed all 
ports and nothing could be done.
I uninstall and cleaned all registers and put BLACK ICE DEFENDER SERVER 
3.55CEH.This product IS BRILLLIANT and SUPER STABLE. It is a real brilliant 
firewall.
Though it does not look at what it goes out as ZA does, then what is that ZA 
does in the end and is good for the operating system, for Apache and the 
rest???

Forget ZA. It is a waste. They put cookie control, pop up and in the end they 
forgot in this tutti fruti to have a decent firewall.

Cheers

Richard Benfatto

Sydney Australia

creator: bz@ldworen.net
text:
I found this site and "bug" report by googling zonealarm and corruption.  (I
don't run apache, but bear with me -- this still looks relevant.)  Until reading
all the info in this bug report, I was running ZoneAlarm 3.1.395 which is either
current or very close.  I'm only had it for a short time, but I've noticed a lot
more corrupted downloads from netnews servers, and redownloading the same file
almost always results in a valid file, meaning the data is good on the news
server.  So I shut down ZA and voila, no more corrupted files.  My system (w2k)
has been up for 18 days, and consistent with the described apache problems with
ZA, it seems that the corruption frequency increases geometrically the longer ZA
is running.  So I'm back to relying on just my LinkSys router/gateway/firewall.
 Sigh.  I'm convinced that there is nothing to be fixed in apache in regards to
the *broken* ZoneAlarm.

creator: jwoolley@apache.org

creator: spam@come.no-ip.com
slive@apache.org
text:
For one thing, you posted to a bug about ZoneAlarm and BSODs when you
use neither ZoneAlarm nor are getting BSODs.  IF this is a valid bug,
it should be posted to a new report, not appended to this one.

But before you do that, make absolutely sure that you UNINSTALL all
your firewall software and reboot your computer to see if that fixes
the problem.  If it does, your problem is almost certainly a faulty
firewall.
ah, yes, you are right..sorry about that...
